Activity

Watch the following video to help you answer the questions below.




  1. Record the weight for the number of oranges in the box from the video.

number of oranges

weight in kilograms

Compare your answers:

  1. Create a scatter plot of the data.

Use the graphing tool here. Then select the Solution button to check your work.



3. Draw a line through the data that fits the data well.

Use the graphing tool here.. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=0.216x+0.345\)



4. Estimate a value for the slope of the line that you drew. What does the value of the slope represent?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer: 

About 0.2. The value represents the approximate weight of each orange added to the box.


5. Estimate the weight of a box containing 11 oranges. Will this estimate be close to the actual value? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

About 2.8 kilograms \((2.6+0.2=2.8)\). The estimate should be close to the actual value since there is only 1 additional orange added, and while there is some variability, it is not great.




6. Estimate the weight of a box containing 50 oranges. Will this estimate be close to the actual value? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

About 10.6 kilograms \((2.6+40⋅0.2=10.6)\). This estimate will probably not be very close. With data only going to 10 oranges, the variability in orange weight will make it harder to get an estimate that is close to the actual value with more oranges. 




7. Estimate the coordinates for the vertical intercept of the line you drew. What might the \(y\)-coordinate for this point represent?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

About 0.3 kilogram. The \(y\)-coordinate estimates the weight of the box with no oranges in it.



8. When you use a linear model to estimate a value in the data given in a scatter plot, that is called interpolation. When you use a linear model to estimate the value outside the data given in the scatter plot, that is called extrapolation.

Which point(s) are best fit by your linear model? How did you decide?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

When there were 6 oranges in the basket, it was closest to my line. I decided this because the line almost goes through that point.




9. Which point(s) fit the least well by your linear model? How did you decide?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

When there were 7 oranges in the basket, it was the worst estimate. I decided this since this point is the farthest from the line.



Compare your line with that of a partner. Discuss why you chose to put your lines where you did. How are your answers different? Which of you has a line that is the better fit? Why?
